docs.lead_paragraph: At the close of a long Congressional debate in 1965 over a bill assuring medical care for the aged, a hastily written measure was tacked on to deal with health care for the poor. The legislative ''sleeper'' was quickly approved. Within the next 15 years, the so-called sleeper, known as Medicaid, mushroomed into a vast, ambitious and controversial Federal and state program that made $21 billion in payments last year. In 1967, the first full year of the Medicaid program, Federal and state payments totaled $1.5 billion. To deal with what the Reagan Administration terms the ''unconstrained growth'' of Medicaid, which is now the fastest growing program in most state budgets, President Reagan has proposed limiting Federal contributions to the program in the hope of saving $1 billion in the fiscal year 1982 and up to $5 billion annually by 1986.

headline.main: U.S. LIMIT ON MEDICAID WOULD SHIFT BURDEN TO STATES

docs.lead_paragraph: A large-scale study has found a sharp reduction in the risk of death for patients taking a drug called timolol after suffering heart attacks, according to a report published yesterday. Use of the drug reduced the patients' overall risk of death in the period of the study by almost 40 percent and cut almost in half the death rate of those who were classified as high-risk patients after their attacks. There were also significantly fewer subsequent heart attacks among the drug-treated group than among comparable patients who did not receive the drug, according to the report in The New England Journal of Medicine. 1,884 Patients in Norway The study was done in Norway by a research team that pooled results from 20 hospitals serving about a third of the country's population. The study, involving 1,884 patients, was done over a period of about three years. The results suggested that the drug holds more promise for the prevention of death or subsequent heart attacks than any other drug extensively studied so far.

headline.main: 3-YEAR STUDY FINDS A HEART DRUG CUTTING DEATH RATE AFTER ATTACKS
